questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication for Hysterosalpingography (HSG)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vaginal bleeding

  • HSG is a procedure in which contrast dye is injected under fluoroscopy to visualize the uterine cavity, fallopian tube architecture, and tubal patency
  • It is performed post menstrual (Day7-9)
    • Indications-
      • Infertility
      • Abnormal bleeding patterns (to rule out intra-uterine lesions like submucous fibroids/ endometrial polyps)
      • Suspected Mullerian anomalies (Which can present as RPL)
  • HSG is contraindicated in:
    • Acute PID
    • Pregnancy
    • Active bleeding

 

 

Ref: Novak 16th edition; pg 2058

questions.text: A 27-year multigravida presents at 6 weeks complaining of fever and a pruritic rash. You diagnose her with varicella zoster virus. Three of your other pregnant patients were in the office waiting room at the same time as this patient and you are concerned, they may have been exposed. Two of them report having a history of varicella during childhood and the 3rd reports no history of either vaccination or natural infection. What is the next best plan for her?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. VZV serological testing followed by varicella zoster Immunoglobulin if seronegative

Explanation

Chickenpox in Pregnancy

There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox

Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox

  • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized)
  • IF immunized, nothing further need be done
  • If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV
  • If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done
  • If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

 

 

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

choices.text: Nitrates and Sildenafil both cause hypertension.
Sildenafil inhibits the metabolism of Nitrates leading to toxicity.
Co-administration can cause severe hypotension due to the potentiation of the action of Nitrates.
There is no specific interaction between Nitrates and Sildenafil.

questions.text: Which of the following explains the reason why Nitrates and Sildenafil should not be prescribed together?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Co-administration can cause severe hypotension due to the potentiation of the action of Nitrates.

Explanation:

Option A is incorrect because both Nitrates and Sildenafil cause vasodilation which would lower, not raise, blood pressure.

Option B is incorrect because Sildenafil doesn't inhibit the metabolism of Nitrates. Instead, it inhibits phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE5), an enzyme that breaks down cGMP.

Option C is correct because Nitrates increase the level of cGMP causing vasodilation and lowering blood pressure. When Sildenafil (a PDE5 inhibitor) is also administered, it prevents the breakdown of cGMP, leading to a further increase in cGMP levels and enhancing the vasodilatory effect of Nitrates. This can cause severe hypotension.

Option D is incorrect because there is a significant interaction between Nitrates and Sildenafil, which can lead to severe hypotension. Therefore, they should not be administered together.

questions.text: A patient arrived at the medical centre reporting persistent abdominal discomfort. Standard diagnostic tests were conducted to determine the cause, but the results did not yield any significant abnormalities. However, a distinctive finding was observed in the course of the patient's stay. The patient's urine, after being left standing for some time, gradually changed to a black color. Given this peculiar observation, which enzymatic function could most likely be compromised in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Homogentisate oxidase

The term alkaptonuria arises from the Arabic word alkapton for ‘alkali’ and Greek word ‘to suck up oxygen greedily in alkali’. This is based on the observation that the urine becomes black on standing when it becomes alkaline.

The disease is autosomal recessive inherited and it is due to the deficiency of the enzyme required for further metabolism of homogentisic acid.

Alkaptonuria and albinism are two inborn errors included in Garrod’s tetrad; the other two being pentosuria and cystinuria. Garrod introduced the term “inborn errors of metabolism”.

It is compatible with fairly normal life. The only abnormality is the blackening of urine on standing. The homogentisic acid is oxidized by polyphenol oxidase to benzoquinone acetate. It is then polymerized to black colored alkapton bodies.

By the 3rd or 4th decade of life, patient may develop ochronosis (deposition of alkapton bodies in intervertebral discs, cartilages of nose, pinna of ear). Black pigments are deposited over the connective tissues including joint cavities to produce arthritis.

Diagnosis of Alkaptonuria

  1. Urine becomes black on standing when it becomes alkaline. Blackening is accelerated on exposure to sunlight and oxygen. The urine when kept in a test tube will start to blacken from the top layer.
  2. Ferric chloride test will be positive for urine.
  3. Benedict’s test is strongly positive. Therefore, alkaptonuria comes under the differential diagnosis of reducing substances in urine

No specific treatment is required. But minimal protein intake with phenylalanine less than 500 mg/day is recommended.

questions.text: Acetylcholine decrease heart rate by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans A. By decreasing the rate of diastolic depolarization of SA node

  • Spontaneous diastolic depolarization (Phase 4 of action potential) of SA node is required for automaticity of SA node.
  • By decreasing the slope of phase 4, acetylcholine decreases the rate of impulse generation and thus decreases heart rate.
  • ACh decreases the AV conduction by increasing the refractory period of AV node and His-Purkinje fibres.

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect regarding Sibsons's fascia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

Sibson's fascia is joined to the first rib's inner border, not the second rib.

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane)

  • Covers the apical portion of the lung and acts as a dividing line between the lower neck and the thorax.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
  • It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles.
  • The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

Clinical significance

  • The suprapleural membrane's function is to protect the apex of the lung (the part that extends outside the rib cage) and the cervical fascia. This aids in resisting intrathoracic pressure changes, preventing neck inflation and deflation during expiration and inspiration, and also providing rigidity to the thoracic inlet.
  • Herniation of the cervical fascia may result due to injury to suprapleural membrane.

questions.text: A bundle of muscle cells is found to contract rhythmically and in unison even when its nerve supply is disrupted. Although muscle contractions are dependent on the presence of extracellular calcium, the cells have poorly developed T tubules. Which of the following most likely describes the muscle type?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Unitary smooth muscle

  • Among the smooth muscles, only unitary smooth muscle can contract rhythmically and in unison without extrinsic innervation.
  • Although all muscles can contract rhythmically and in unison under the right conditions, skeletal muscle can do so only by being activated by its motor nerves.
  • Unitary smooth muscle: Muscle that contracts and relaxes as a unit.
  • Multiunit smooth muscle: Muscle that, like skeletal muscle, acts independently in contraction and relaxation.
  • All smooth muscles exhibit length–force (tension) relationships similar to those seen in striated muscle, even though sarcomeres are absent in smooth muscle.
  • Calcium initiates contraction by binding with calmodulin, which in turn activates a kinase that phosphorylates smooth muscle myosin, which then can interact with actin.

 

Other Options

Option A. Cardiac muscle does not need innervation to contract rhythmically in unison and does require extracellular calcium; however, it has highly developed T tubules.

Option B. Skeletal muscle also does not require extracellular calcium.

Option D. This is a case of smooth muscle, not skeletal muscle.

questions.text: Neurological symptoms are observed in all of the following diseases EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gaucher's disease

  • Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by the deficiency of an enzyme called glucocerebrosidase.
  • This deficiency leads to the accumulation of a fatty substance called glucocerebroside within certain cells, primarily affecting the spleen, liver, and bone marrow.
  • While Gaucher's disease can cause a wide range of symptoms, including enlargement of the spleen and liver, anemia, and bone problems, it typically does not result in prominent neurological symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Option A. Tay-Sachs disease

    • Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the nerve cells of the brain and spinal cord.
    • This accumulation leads to progressive damage to the nervous system, causing neurological symptoms such as developmental regression, muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures.

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a group of inherited metabolic disorders that result in the accumulation of lipids, particularly sphingomyelin, in various tissues and organs.
  • Different subtypes of Niemann-Pick disease exist, but most of them involve neurological symptoms. These symptoms may include progressive intellectual and motor decline, seizures, muscle stiffness, and impaired coordination.

Option D. GM1 gangliosidosis

  • GM1 gangliosidosis is also a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of an enzyme called beta-galactosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of GM1 ganglioside in various tissues, including the brain and nerve cells.
  • The neurological symptoms of GM1 gangliosidosis are progressive and include developmental regression, muscle stiffness, seizures, loss of motor skills, and intellectual disability.

In summary, while neurological symptoms are observed in Tay-Sachs disease, Niemann-Pick disease, and GM1 gangliosidosis, they are not typically observed in Gaucher's disease, making it the exception among the given options.

questions.text: Imipenem is active against which of the following organism/s?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All the above 

Imipenem

  • Imipenem is a broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic that has activity against both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, including many multidrug-resistant organisms.
  • It is effective against a wide range of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria like:
    • Gram-positive cocci, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pneumoniae.
    • Gram-negative bacilli, such as Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae.
    • Anaerobes, such as Bacteroides fragilis and Clostridium difficile.
  • Therefore, imipenem is often used as an empiric therapy for severe infections, particularly those caused by multidrug-resistant organisms or in immunocompromised patients.

Other Important Points to be Remember:

  • A limiting feature of imipenem is its rapid hydrolysis by the enzyme dehydropeptidase-1 located on the brush border of renal tubular cells.
  • An innovative solution to this problem is its combination with cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase I, which has matched pharmacokinetics with imipenem (t 1/2 of both is 1hr) and protects it.
  • Imipenem-cilastatin has proved effective in a wide range of serious hospital acquired respiratory, urinary, abdominal, pelvic, skin, and soft tissue infections including those in neutropenic, cancer and AIDS patients. For Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections, it should be combined with gentamicin.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought with complaints of squeezing his eyes while looking at distant objects. He also holds his books very close to his face while reading. What should be the next line of management of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Assess for refractive error

Although blurry-distant-vision is the primary symptom of myopia, children are too young or unaware to discern it or complain about it.

Secondary symptoms may indicate the presence of refractive error in child. Some of the common secondary symptoms to watch out for include sitting too close to the TV or holding books up close in the face. Take notice if child suddenly loses interest in sports that require good distant vision.

Myopia is the most common type of refractive error found in children

Myopia or short-sightedness: Myopia is a defect in the vision, in which a person can see nearby objects clearly but cannot see the distant objects distinctly after a certain limit. This defect is common among children.

The causes of Myopia are: 

  1. The eyeball gets elongated along its axis so that the distance between eye lens and retina becomes larger.
  2. Due to excessive curvature of cornea, the focal length of eye becomes small.

questions.text: Identify the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans C. Trabeculectomy Bleb

Trabeculectomy is a filtering surgery where an ostium is created into the anterior chamber from underneath a partial thickness scleral flap to allow for aqueous flow out of the eye. The aqueous flows into the subconjunctival space, usually leading to an elevation of the conjunctiva, referred to as a filtering bleb. There are several suggested routes for the aqueous after reaching the filtering bleb. These routes include filtration through the conjunctiva into the tear film, absorption by vascular or perivascular conjunctival tissue, flow through lymphatic vessels near the margins of the surgical area, and drainage through aqueous veins. Trabeculectomy is performed for treatment of glaucoma inadequately controlled by maximally tolerated medical therapy. 

Limbal dermoids are congenital benign tumors that can cause visual abnormalities due to the development of astigmatism, encroachment on the visual axis, and fatty component infiltration into the cornea.

Ciliary Staphyloma- As the name implies, it is the bulge of weak sclera lined by ciliary body, which occurs about 2–3 mm away from the limbus. Its common causes are thinning of sclera following perforating injury, scleritis & absolute glaucoma. It is a part of anterior staphyloma.

questions.text: A fourteen-year-old boy presents with right sided acute onset scrotal pain. Examination reveals tenderness which worsens on lifting the testis. Which of these is the most common anatomical abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. High investment of tunica vaginalis

The given scenario is suggestive of testicular torsion.

Pain worsening on elevation of testis is seen in torsion and used to differentiate it from acute epididymo-orchitis – Prehn’s sign.

Anatomical factors:

  1. High investment of the tunica vaginalis, causing the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality.
  2. Inversion of the testis: the testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
  3. Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis, permitting torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is referred by her paediatrician for evaluation of esotropia. Ophthalmologic examination reveals esotropia in the primary position with markedly limited abduction of the left eye, although there is minimal restriction of adduction of the left eye and lid fissure narrowing on attempted adduction. Right ocular motility and fissure height are normal.  This case most likely represents which one of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Duane’s retraction syndrome (DRS) type I 

DRS occurs in approximately 1% of all patients with strabismus. Its clinical features include a unilateral or bilateral abnormality of horizontal gaze, retraction of the globe on attempted adduction, and upshooting or down shooting of the globe on adduction. The left eye is affected more frequently than the right, and females are affected more frequently than males. DRS may be divided into three types. DRS type I is characterized by marked limitation of abduction with normal or minimal restriction of adduction. DRS type II is characterized by marked limitation of adduction with normal or minimal restriction of abduction. DRS type III is characterized by marked restriction of abduction as well as adduction.

Type I is the most common form of DRS, and type III is the least common. Although the majority of patients with DRS type I and type II will have straight eyes, some type I patients develop an esodeviation in primary position and some type II patients develop an exodeviation. Amblyopia may be present in some patients with DRS.

Brown syndrome Ocular features include mechanical restriction syndrome attributed to the superior oblique tendon sheath. It is characterized by the inability to actively or passively elevate the eye in the adducted position. It may be acquired or congenital. There is normal or nearly normal elevation of the eye in abduction.

Cogan’s Syndrome

Ocular features include interstitial keratitis, reduced vision mainly with the involvement of center of the cornea, very fine wavy lines resembling fingerprints within or very close to corneal epithelium and best seen on biomicroscopy with retroillumination. Systemic features are sensorineural deafness, tinnitus, vertigo, systemic vasculitis (including life-threatening aortitis).

Posner-Schlossman Syndrome (Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis)

Ocular features include slight blurring of vision and colored halos during episodes of high intraocular tension, glaucomatocyclitic crisis (benign and usually unilateral), enlarged pupil, anisocoria, absence of ciliary or conjunctival injection, only trace of aqueous flare, no posterior synechiae, chamber angle open, heterochromia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath, heart palpitations, and a fear that she is “going crazy”. She has no history of similar episodes. On examination, her heart rate is 110 bpm, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, and her physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory tests, including complete blood count, electrolytes, cardiac enzymes, and thyroid function tests, are within normal limits. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no ST or T wave changes. Based on the most likely diagnosis, what is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Administer oral benzodiazepines

Explanation:

This patient’s symptoms of palpitations, shortness of breath, and the fear of going crazy are suggestive of a panic attack. In the acute setting, the first line treatment for a panic attack is a benzodiazepine, which can provide immediate relief from acute symptoms. Benzodiazepines can be administered orally in this case as the patient is conscious, cooperative, and able to swallow. Cognitive-behavioral therapy and SSRIs are effective for long-term management of panic disorder, but they do not provide the immediate relief that is necessary in an acute panic attack. Furosemide is a diuretic and is not indicated in this case.

choices.text: Increases by 40-45% of nonpregnant volume
Increases with gestational age and plateaus at 34 weeks
By 12 weeks, plasma volume expands by approximately 30%
Increase is 40-80% with multifetal gestation

questions.text: What is not true about blood volume in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. By 12 weeks, plasma volume expands by approximately 30%

Explanation: 

  • Hypervolemia in pregnancy averages 40-45% above the non-pregnant blood volume
  • This value is reached by 32 -34 weeks
  • In individual women, expansion varies considerably
  • Maternal blood volume begins to accrue during the first trimester and by 12 weeks is approximately 15% that of pre pregnancy values
  • In multiple pregnancies, the blood volume increase is even more drastic ranging between 40 – 80%

 

 

Ref: Page No 57, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Given that the percentage of cytosine in a DNA molecule is 22%, according to Chargaff’s rule, what is the percentage of guanine in the same DNA molecule?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 22%

Explanation: According to Chargaff’s rule, in DNA molecules, the concentration of adenine equals that of thymine, and the concentration of guanine equals that of cytosine. Therefore, if the percentage of cytosine in the DNA is 22%, the percentage of guanine would also be 22%.

choices.text: Inducing enzymes such as PEPCK, glucose 6 phosphatase and fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase to favor gluconeogenesis
Increasing plasma free fatty acid level and favoring beta oxidation in adipose tissue
Stimulating insulin production to reduce blood glucose levels

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a function of glucagon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stimulating insulin production to reduce blood glucose levels

Explanation: Glucagon primarily acts to raise blood glucose levels, opposing the action of insulin. It does this by stimulating glycogenolysis (the breakdown of glycogen into glucose), depressing glycogen synthesis, and promoting gluconeogenesis (the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors). Additionally, glucagon increases plasma free fatty acid levels and favors beta oxidation in adipose tissue. However, glucagon does not stimulate insulin production; rather, it is anti-insulin in nature.

choices.text: Folliculogenesis is entirely under control of FSH
Estrogen is secreted by the theca cells of pre-antral & antral follicles
The Graafian follicle is selected based on the number of FSH receptors on its surface.
The tertiary follicle contains secondary oocyte along with granulosa & theca cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about folliculogenesis is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The Graafian follicle is selected based on the number of FHS receptors on its surface

  1. Initial folliculogenesis is hormone independent until the secondary follicle stage after which it is dependent on FSH and LH.
  2. Estrogen is formed by granulosa cells under the influence of FSH; Theca cells provide testosterone for aromatization in granulosa cells as per the 2-cell 2 -gonadotropin theory
  3. Follicle containing maximum number of FSH receptors will mature to Graafian follicle
  4. Tertiary follicle & all other follicles contain the primary oocyte. Secondary oocyte is formed just before the Graafian follicle ruptures.

 

 

Ref: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology – 16th edition page no 286 – 88

choices.text: Cathode ray tube
Dark field/ Phase condenser

questions.text: Mechanism by which students view this image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dichroic mirror

Explanation:

  • The picture shows a specimen under fluorescence microscope.
  • The specimen is illuminated with light of a specific band, which is absorbed by the fluorescent dye, causing it to emit light of a weaker band and hence a different color.
  • In a properly configured microscope, only the emission light should reach the eye or detector and not the illuminating light scattered by the background
  • This produces a high contrast image where the fluorescent structures are superimposed on a dark background.
  • The dichroic mirrors used in fluorescence microscopes allow the weaker emitted light to pass through it while reflecting the illuminating light back.

questions.text: Corynebacterium diphtheria becomes infective after the transfer of a fragment of chromosome, this process is known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Transduction

Explanation:

Transformation:

  • Transformation is the transfer of genetic information through the agency of free DNA.
  • Ex:  transfer of genetic information for capsular synthesis from heat killed capsulated S.  pneumoniae to  the  live  non-capsulated  S. pneumoniae in experiment by Griffith.

Transduction:

  • Transduction is the transfer of cell DNA from one cell to another by means of bacteriophages.
  • Diphtheria toxin, botulinum toxin, cholera toxin and streptococcus pyogenes toxin are encoded by bacteriophage and can be transferred by transduction.

Conjugation:

  • Conjugation is the transfer of cell DNA from one cell to another by means of the sex pili.

Important points:

Transfection:

  • When purified DNA is injected into the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell, the process is called transfection.
  • Transfection is frequently used in genetic engineering procedures.

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Continue treatment for another 2 years
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment
Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics

questions.text: A 16-year-old who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Continue treatment for another 2 years

Anti-epileptics once initiated must be continued for a minimum period of 2 years. Decision to stop AED is considered if seizure free>2 years with Normal EEG, normal neurological examination, no family history of seizure/epilepsy and single seizure type.

Most recurrences occur in the first 3 months of discontinuing AED.

Option A. Stopping AED abruptly may lead to recurrence of seizure

Option C. Gradually tapering is considered only if patient seizure free for minimum 2 years

Option D. Not recommended lifelong unless refractory epilepsy/seizures.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is currently on her 28th week of gestation. She has a long history of major depressive disorder for which she has been taking paroxetine. Which of the following conditions is the neonate at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

Explanation:

Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) commonly used to treat major depressive disorder. While generally considered safe in pregnancy, it has been associated with an increased risk of persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) when used in late pregnancy.

Neural tube defects and cleft palate are not specifically associated with paroxetine use in pregnancy.

Down syndrome is a genetic disorder associated with maternal age and is not related to paroxetine use.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her concerned mother. Her mother tells you that the patient has not yet attained menarche. She is performing well in school and takes part in several sports activities. On examination, you note that the breast and pubic hair are Tanner stage 1. Her height is appropriate. On evaluation, her FSH and LH are low. What could be a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Physiological delay

  • This patient has hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhoea with absence of secondary sexual characters.
  • Causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism are:
    1. Physiological delay (most common cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism)
    2. Kallmann syndrome (2nd most common cause – associated with anosmia)
    3. Others
      • CNS Tumors (most common CNS tumor associated with amenorrhea is Craniopharyngioma)
      • Developmental/genetic defects
      • Trauma
      • Inflammatory process
      • Functional GnRH deficiency

 

 

Ref: Berek and Novak 16th edition; pg 1866

choices.text: REM sleep behavior disorder

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Orthostatic hypotension

Orthostatic hypotension is not a core but supportive criteria in DLB.

Option A, B, C are core criteria in the diagnosis of DLB.

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB)

Core Clinical criteria include the following.

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD)
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism

Supportive: Not having high specificity. However they are seen during the course of the disease

Severe sensitivity to anti-psychotic drugs, autonomic dysfunction, Other types of hallucination

**Onset of dementia preceeding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

questions.text: A non-obese 50-year-old male presents with fairly widespread involvement of the above condition as well as rugose hypertrophy of the palmar skin. Which of the following associations is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gastric cancer

Type I acanthosis nigricans is associated with malignancy. Rugose hypertrophy of the palms is referred to as tripe palms (acanthosis palmaris). Ninety-five percent of patients with tripe palms will have cancer, and almost 80% will have associated acanthosis nigricans. In patients with tripe palms alone, the most common associated malignancy is lung cancer. In patients with both tripe palms and acanthosis nigricans, the most common association is gastric cancer.

choices.text: N Acetyl Cysteine

questions.text:
A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department after she collapsed outside a bar.

Physical Examination: T: 97.5°F HR: 60 bpm RR: 5 breaths per minute BP: 75/57 mm Hg

Pupils are miotic but equal.

Respiratory system: Clear to auscultation.

CVS: Regular rate and rhythm.

 Abdomen: Normal

Neurologic: GCS = 6 (E1V1M4).

What would be the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Naloxone

  • It is a case of opioid poisoning
  • The classic presentation of an opiate poisoning usually consists of the triad of CNS depression, respiratory depression and miosis. Hypotension can also occur.
  • Both Naloxone and naltrexone are opioid “antagonists”.
  • Naloxone acts very fast, whereas, Naltrexone acts more slowly/long term.
  • Hence while naloxone is used to treat opioid overdose, naltrxone is used to treat alcohol and opioid dependence.
  • Naltrexone decreases cravings by blocking the effects of alcohol and opioids by binding to the endorphin receptors in the body and blocking opioid receptors in the brain. This function helps maintain abstinence and prolong recovery.
  • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist. This patient is comatose (GCS 6). Benzodiazepines alone are unlikely to cause coma, they just make the person drowsy and sleepy
  • N-acetylcysteine is used to treat acetaminophen overdose. In Acetaminophen poisoning there are symptoms of hepatotoxicity like vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice etc.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the opening of the inlet of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroepiglottic

The thyroepiglottic muscle is responsible for opening the inlet of the larynx. It is part of the intrinsic musculature of the larynx and helps regulate the aperture of the larynx during breathing and swallowing.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280m wavelength?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tryptophan

To increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm, alanine should be replaced by tryptophan.

The amino acids which absorb UV light at 250-290m (maximum at 280m) are

  • Tryptophan (Maximum Absorption)
  • Tyrosine
  • Phenylalanine

Bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis and partial steroid response is suggestive of NMO-Spectrum disorder.

Option B. MS usually causes U/L optic neuritis. LETM (Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis) not common in MS

Option C. SACD usually affects the posterior column. LETM, optic neuritis not a feature of B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida presents to the LR at midnight. She complains of vaginal leaking since several hours. On examination, the uterus is term with the fetus in transverse lie but you are unable to auscultate the fetal heart and on vaginal exam, you note the umbilical cord is lying in the vagina. The cervix is 5 cm dilated with the presenting part high up. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Emergency LSCS

Explanation

  • This is a scenario of transverse lie
  • Even though fetal demise has occurred (due to cord prolapse), the treatment of choice is cesarean section otherwise she will have obstructed labor
  • There is no role of ECV intrapartum in a singleton pregnancy
  • IPV is done only if 2nd of twin is transverse lie and if external version has failed

questions.text: In a given population, the average value is 150. If the standard deviation is 10, what range will encompass approximately 68% of the population?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. 140 - 160

For a normal distribution, 68.3% data falls within three one standard deviations of the mean. So, in this case, with a mean of 150 and a standard deviation of 10, 68% of the data will fall between 140 (150 - 10) and 160 (150 + 10).

questions.text: A 21-year-old Caucasian man presents with a two-month history of painless lesions on his penis. He denies any fever, night sweats or weight loss, and he has also not noticed any dysuria or urethral discharge. He discloses that he has two sexual partners and he regularly has unprotected sex with both of them. On examination of his genitalia, there are five pink verrucous papules on the penile shaft. Which virus is most likely responsible for this patient's genital lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. HPV 6

Explanation: Genital warts are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV-6 and HPV-11 are the cause of approximately 90% of genital warts. Genital warts are a very common sexually transmitted disease affecting both men and women.

The available treatment modalities include:

  1. Cryotherapy,
  2. Podophyllin resin,
  3. Trichloroacetic acid applications,
  4. Electrosurgery curettage and
  5. Scissor or scalpel excision,
  6. Laser ablation and
  7. 5% fluorouracil cream.

The HPV types that cause external visible warts (HPV Types 6 and 11) rarely cause cancer. Other HPV types (most often Types 16, 18, 31, 33 and 35) are less common in visible warts but are strongly associated with anogenital cancer, including squamous intraepithelial lesions and invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

 

 

Reference:  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5388291/

choices.text: It's a more powerful vasoconstrictor than angiotensin II.
Concentration of circulating blood vasopressin after severe hemorrhage can increase enough to attenuate reductions in arterial pressure markedly.
Uses adenylyl cyclase-cAMP as well as phospholipase C system.
Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect about vasopressin?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus

Paraventricular nucleus secretes oxytocin and supraoptic nucleus secretes vasopressin.

  • Physiology Of ADH

It increases the water permeability of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct cells in the kidney to increase water reabsorption.

The stimulus for secretion is ↑ plasma osmolality, with the exception of the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of ADH (SIADH), in which ADH is elevated despite decreased plasma osmolality.

Drug Class: Vasoconstrictor & Anti-Diuretic Hormone (ADH)

  • Mechanism of Action:

Supraphysiologic concentrations: vasopressin constricts arterial blood vessels by binding to vascular V1 vascular receptors. This makes it potentially useful in maintaining arterial blood pressure in a setting of cardiac arrest.

Normal physiologic concentrations: Stimulation of V2 receptors in the cell membrane of the collecting duct promotes the translocation and insertion of aquaporin 2 water channel containing vesicles, into the collecting duct apical membrane.

Option: A. Vasopressin, also called antidiuretic hormone, is even more powerful than angiotensin II as a vasoconstrictor, thus making it one of the body’s most potent vascular constrictor substances. It is formed in nerve cells in the hypothalamus of the brain

Option: B. Vasopressin could have enormous effects on circulatory function. Yet, because only minute amounts of vasopressin are secreted in most physiological conditions, most physiologists have thought that vasopressin plays little role in vascular control. However, experiments have shown that the concentration of circulating blood vasopressin after severe hemorrhage can increase enough to attenuate reductions in arterial pressure markedly. In some cases, this action can, by itself, bring the arterial pressure almost back up to normal.

Option: C. Uses adenylyl cyclase-cAMP on V2 as well as phospholipase C system on V1.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with symptoms including thickening of the skin, enlarged hands and feet, protruding jaw, and excessive sweating. Blood tests reveal an elevated growth hormone (GH) level. His physician decides to prescribe a growth hormone receptor antagonist as a treatment option. Which of the following drugs is most likely being considered?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pegvisomant

 The above clinical features of chin protrusion, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance and hand and foot enlargement are suggestive of Acromegaly.

Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist that can be used to treat this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient who presents with diarrhea and abdominal discomfort is found at colonoscopy to have colitis confined to the transverse and descending colon. A biopsy is performed. Which of the following is a finding consistent with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Non-caseating granulomas can be expected in up to 50% of patients.

The limited colonic involvement with predominant diarrhoea is suggestive of Crohn’s disease. In Ulcerative colitis, disease begins in rectum, which is not seen here.

CD (see Crohn’s disease (regional enteritis)) is characterised by discontinuous transmural inflammation of the bowel, of any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, but most commonly the ileocaecal region, colon and anus. There is often a degree of rectal sparing when the colon is involved.

The transmural inflammation may be patchy (rather than diffuse) and crypt distortion is commonly seen.

Histology typically demonstrates discontinuous segments of disease or ‘skip lesions’, involvement of the terminal ileum and the presence of granulomas with a tendency for more marked inflammation in the proximal colon.

questions.text: A patient with renal failure develops vomiting in ICU. ABG analysis showed pH - 7.4, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L, HC03- = 24mEq/L, PaC02 = 40 mmHg. What is the likely metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

Clinical history of renal failure should hint towards possibility of preexisting metabolic acidosis. Important in MCQs to always calculate AG even if ABG appears normal.

AG: 145-(100+24) = 21 (Normal ~12)

Excess unmeasured anion(H) combine with HCO3 thereby reducing the HCO3 proportionately. Hence Delta ratio i.e ΔAG(AG-12) /ΔHCO3(24-HCO3) = >2.

Value >2 indicate coexisting Metabolic alkalosis

Option D. HAGMA+ NAGMA is suggested by Delta ratio between (0.4-0.8)

Option A, B are not appropriate choices for the given question.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Epinephrine

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are as follows:

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

choices.text: VC normal but FEV1 reduces
VC reduces but FEV1 is normal
FEV1/FVC ratio normal
Functional residual capacity reduces

questions.text: A 40 years old male diagnosed with bronchial asthma since last 10 years. Pulmonary function tests are done to assess lung functions. Which of the following is true:
questions.solution:
Ans: A. VC normal but FEV1 reduces
 

Forced expiratory volume is first second is FEV1. FEV1 -80% of FVC. In obstructive disorders – like asthma, inspiration is normal but expiration is obstructed. So, VC normal but FEV1 reduces.
 

Other Options:
 

Option: B. VC reduces but FEV1 is normal

In restrictive disorders – like pulmonary fibrosis, chest expansion is restricted. So, VC reduces but FEV1 is normal.
 

Option: C. FEV1/FVC ratio normal

In obstructive disorders – like asthma, inspiration is normal but expiration is obstructed. So, VC normal but FEV1 reduces.

So FEV1/FVC ratio reduces according to the severity of the disease.
 

Option: D. Functional residual capacity reduces

FRC is the volume of air which is contained in the lungs at end of tidal expiration. In obstructive disorder expiration is obstructed, so FRC increases.

choices.text: Increase in thirst

questions.text: Which of the following events occurs during phase B to raise body temperature to hypothalamus set point?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Shivering

  • Shivering -the shivering center is located in posterior hypothalamus. It is normally inhibited by signals from heat center in hypothalamic-preoptic area but is excited by cold signals from skin and spinal cord.
  • A sudden increase in heat setpoint results in activation of this center .it then transmits non rhythmic signals through bilateral tracts through the lateral columns of spinal cord, and finally to the anterior motor neurons. They increase the tone of skeletal muscles throughout the body.
  • As, the tone rises above a certain critical level, shivering begins. During Maximum shivering, the body heat production can rise to four to five times the normal.
  • Vasoconstriction (decreased blood flow to skin) is mediated by increased sympathetic drive by the activation of the posterior hypothalamic sympathetic center.

choices.text: P. malariae and P. vivax
P. falciparum and P. vivax
P. ovale and P. vivax
P. malariae and P. ovale

questions.text: Malaria relapses common with which type of plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. P. ovale and P. vivax

Explanation:

Relapse of malaria:

  • Occurs in P. vivax and P. ovale infections
  • Due  to  persistent  hypnozoites  in  the  liver  which  may  cause resurgence  of  erythrocytic  cycle  after  a  period  of  their disappearance form the peripheral blood
  • Can occur up to 5 years after primary infection
  • Can  be  prevented  by  radical  cure  with  Primaquine  to  eradicate hypnozoites

Recrudescence of malaria:

  • Recurrence  of  malaria  in  species  which  lack  hypnozoites  is called recrudescence to differentiate it from relapse
  • Occurs in P. falciparum and P. malariae
  • Infection  recurs  from  persistent  blood  stages  (erythrocytic stage) of the malaria parasite.
  • Can be seen for 1-2 years in P. falciparum and up to 50 years in P. malariae
  • Can  be  prevented  by  adequate  drug  therapy  and  use  of  newer drugs in resistant cases

questions.text: Which of the following is a antagonist of PAR-1 receptors of thrombin?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Vorapaxar

  • Vorapaxar is a medication that belongs to the class of drugs known as protease-activated receptor (PAR)-1 inhibitors. It works by selectively blocking the PAR-1 receptor, which is found on the surface of platelets. When PAR-1 is activated by thrombin, it triggers a series of biochemical events that lead to platelet activation and aggregation, ultimately resulting in the formation of a blood clot. By blocking PAR-1, Vorapaxar prevents this process from occurring, thus reducing the risk of blood clots.
  • Prasugrel and Ticlopidine are antiplatelet drugs that act as P2Y12 receptor inhibitors.

Tirofiban is a GPIIb/IIIa receptor inhibitor. This group is strongest anti-platelet drugs.

choices.text: Decreased heart rate
Decreased respiratory rate
Increased alveolar dead space

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath. She has a history of blood clots and is currently not taking any medication for prevention. If she has a pulmonary embolism, what physiological change will most likely be present?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Increased alveolar dead space

  • A pulmonary embolism blocks blood flow to the affected alveolar region. Although the alveoli of this region are ventilated with air, they are not perfused with blood (alveolar dead space ventilation).

Pulmonary embolism alters alveolar dead space and end-tidal carbon dioxide. EtCO2 = end-tidal carbon dioxide; PACO 2 = partial pressure of alveolar carbon dioxide; PVCO 2 = partial pressure mixed venous carbon dioxide

  • Other options:

Option: A. A pulmonary embolism will reduce blood flow to the left ventricle (LV), thus decreasing LV preload and cardiac output. As compensation, heart rate will increase, leading to tachycardia.

Option: B. Tachypnea, not bradypnea (reduced respiratory rate), is typically seen with pulmonary embolism.

Option: C. Hyperventilation, not hypoventilation, is typically seen with pulmonary embolism.

choices.text: MRI of chest

choices.text: Inhibition of M2 receptor
Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA Polymerase
Apoptosis of infected cells

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Oseltamivir as an antiviral agent is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Neuraminidase inhibition

  • Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication used to treat and prevent influenza infections. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of the neuraminidase enzyme, which is a glycoprotein present on the surface of influenza viruses. Neuraminidase is responsible for cleaving sialic acid residues on the host cells and viral particles, allowing the newly synthesized virus to be released from the host cell and spread to other cells. By inhibiting neuraminidase, oseltamivir prevents the release of newly synthesized viral particles, thereby slowing down the spread of the virus and reducing the severity and duration of influenza symptoms. Oseltamivir is most effective when given within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms and is not a substitute for influenza vaccination.
  • Amantadine and Rimantadine are antiviral medications that work by inhibiting the M2 protein ion channel on the influenza virus, which is required for viral replication.
  • RNA dependent DNA polymerase is the other name of reverse transcriptase. This enzyme is inhibited by drugs like zidovudine, lamivudine etc.
  • Apoptosis or programmed cell death of infected cells is a natural mechanism by which the body eliminates infected cells. However, there are currently no antiviral medications that directly induce apoptosis of infected cells.

choices.text: Vocal polyp, Vocal nodule, Vocal granuloma, reinke’s oedema

questions.text: Identify in the sequence?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Vocal nodule, Vocal polyp, Reinke’s oedema, Vocal granuloma

Vocal nodules (singer’s / screamer’s / teacher’s nodules) -

Commonly seen in teachers, actors, vendors, school children. Bilateral always.

Common site – junction of anterior 1/3rd & posterior 2/3rd of vocal cord (as this is the most prominent area rubbing each other while speech). Sessile.

Pathogenesis – Trauma → submucosal oedema & haemorrhage → hyalinisation & fibrosis

Complaint – hoarseness of voice (professional history will give clue), laryngoscopy confirms the diagnosis

Rx – Voice rest, Speech therapy, Microlaryngeal surgery if persistent.

Vocal polyps -

Exophytic lesion with thin mucosa.

Typically unilateral but can be bilateral. Pedunculated.

Common at junction of anterior 1/3rd & posterior 2/3rd of vocal cord.

A disorganized gelatinous material in the sub-epithelial space.

Complaint – Hoarseness of voice, Diplophonia (double voice)

Rx – Microlaryngeal surgery followed by speech therapy.

Reinke’s oedema (Polypoid corditis) –

Diffuse collection of oedema fluid in sub-epithelial space

97% - smokers (most common cause)

Saddle-bag appearance of vocal cords on laryngoscopy

Rx – Microlaryngeal surgery

Vocal fold granuloma –

Inflammatory tissue arising from perichondrium near the arytenoid cartilage.

Classically seen after endotracheal intubation.

Other causes - laryngopharyngeal reflux, vocal misuse or hyperfunction, glottal incompetence with severe hyperfunction.

Complaints - Globus sensation, dysphonia, and/or odynophonia.

Surgery if suspected of malignancy or infection, (or) all nonsurgical treatment options have been  exhausted.

questions.text:
Choose the true statements about Schatzki ring:

  1. Constriction at lower third esophagus at squamo-columnar junction
  2. Ring is often associated with hiatus hernia
  3. Biopsy shows intestinal metaplasia without Goblet cells seen in Barretts
  4. Rx is anti-reflux surgery
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 1 and 2

A Schatzki’s ring (also known as oesophageal B ring; an A ring is located a few centimetres proximal to the B ring, if found) is a mucosal band found at the squamocolumnar junction and is not an uncommon cause of food impaction in adults.

Radiological studies using barium contrast by Schatzki demonstrated that, in individuals with a ring size of less than 13 mm, the symptom of dysphagia may occur.

The exact aetiology of Schatzki’s ring is uncertain but is believed to be related to GORD; hiatus hernia is more common. Treatment is by endoscopic dilatation if symptomatic with dysphagia.

choices.text: In cost-benefit analysis, the benefits are always expressed in terms of health outcomes like births prevented or illnesses avoided.
Cost-effective analysis primarily focuses on monetary costs and benefits of a health program.
Input-output analysis refers to the relationship between the health service activities consumed (like manpower, money, materials, and time) and useful outcomes such as cases treated or lives saved.
Network analysis is a financial assessment tool that calculates the total cost of all events and activities to be completed to reach an end objective.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE about the different economic analysis techniques used in health programs?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Input-output analysis refers to the relationship between the health service activities consumed (like manpower, money, materials, and time) and useful outcomes such as cases treated or lives saved.

Input-output analysis is a type of economic analysis that examines the relationship between the inputs consumed in the process of providing a service (such as health care) and the outputs or results of that service, such as the number of patients treated or lives saved.

In cost-benefit analysis, while the benefits of a program are expressed in terms of health outcomes when possible, they are ideally represented in monetary terms for direct comparison with the program's cost. In cost-effective analysis expresses the benefits in terms of results achieved, like number of lives saved or number of days free from disease, not primarily in monetary terms. Network analysis is not a financial assessment tool, but a project management tool which maps out all the tasks that need to be completed to reach an end objective.

questions.text: Increased Q angle predisposes to:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Lateral patellar subluxation

Q angle provides a lateral vector to patella and is line between Quadriceps and Patellar tendon. Increase in Q angle predisposes patella to lateral overload and makes it prone to subluxate or dislocate laterally. It is best measured in 30° of knee flexion to center patella in trochlea. questions.text:
Following consumption of a heavy meal with alcoholic binge, patient presents with severe upper abdominal, vomiting,
and retrosternal pain. Abdominal exam shows epigastric tenderness. Serum lipase is 200, chest X ray shows left pleural effusion. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. CECT Thorax + Abdomen

Given scenario is suggestive of spontaneous esophageal perforation or Boerhaave syndrome. Spontaneous emetogenic perforation (Boerhaave’s syndrome) results from a sudden increase in oesophageal pressure against a closed glottis.

Patients with Boerhaave’s syndrome may have the classic triad of vomiting, chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema. There may or may not be associated haematemesis. Typically, the site of perforation is the lower oesophagus towards the left pleural cavity. Gastric juice as well as ingested food is forcefully ejected into the left chest. A left pleural effusion rapidly accumulates.

Physical examination reveals subcutaneous emphysema on the chest wall, sometimes extending to the cervical region as well. In the presence of sepsis, the patient will run a fever, has tachycardia and appears tachypnoeic. Hamman’s sign refers to a crunching sound on auscultation of the heart owing to surgical emphysema

In patients with significant pleural fluid and pneumothorax that result in respiratory compromise, a wide-bore chest tube is inserted to the appropriate side for drainage while waiting for more definitive investigations such as a CT scan.

Project MONICA (MONItoring trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) was an international collaborative study that aimed to monitor trends and determinants of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in different populations. It was conducted in 21 countries across Europe, Asia, and Australia between 1982 and 1997.

The study collected data on CVD risk factors, such as blood pressure, cholesterol levels, smoking habits, and diabetes, as well as clinical events, such as heart attacks and strokes. questions.text: Calculating one variable using another variable is done by?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Coefficient of Regression

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

questions.text: A group of scientists collected data on the height of a particular species of tree in a forest. They want to calculate a statistical measure that would express the dispersion or variation in the tree heights around the mean. Which of the following statistics should they calculate?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Standard deviation

Standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values. It is a popular measure of variability because it returns to the original units of measure of the data set. A low standard deviation means that the values tend to be close to the mean (also called the expected value) of the set, while a high standard deviation means that the values are spread out over a wider range. Thus, in this case, if the scientists want to calculate a measure that expresses the dispersion in the tree heights around the mean, they should calculate the standard deviation.

questions.text: A patient with acute lymphoblastic Leukemia is being treated with a medication that interferes with protein synthesis by causing the breakdown of asparagine. Which of the following drugs is this patient likely receiving?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. L-Asparaginase

Explanation:

Each of the listed drugs has a different mechanism of action.

  1. 6-Mercaptopurine is a purine analog that acts by inhibiting purine synthesis, which is required for the synthesis of DNA during the S phase of the cell cycle.
  2. Mitomycin is an alkylating agent, leading to DNA damage by creating cross links.
  3. Actinomycin causes single strand breaks in DNA and blocks RNA transcription.
  4. L-Asparaginase is the correct answer. It works by breaking down asparagine, an amino acid that is essential for protein synthesis and the growth of cancer cells. Some cancer cells, such as those in acute lymphoblastic leukemia, are unable to make enough asparagine and are dependent on the supply of asparagine from the blood. By breaking down asparagine, L-Asparaginase deprives the cancer cells of this necessary amino acid and inhibits their growth.

questions.text: The Management by Objective (MBO) technique is based on which type of sciences?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Behavioral sciences

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

Methods based on behavioral sciences include:

  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives

(MBO) Quantitative methods includes -

  • Cost-benefit analysis
  • Cost-effective analysis
  • Cost-accounting
  • Input-output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis (CPM)
  • Planning-programming-budgeting system (PBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making

Ans A. Topical tetracycline

Angular conjunctivitis was first described in 1896 by two scientists – French and German ophthalmologists V. Morax and K. Axenfeld, who studied the morphology of the diplobacillus.

Symptoms of angular conjunctivitis

The duration of the incubation period is on average 4 days.

The lesion of the eyes is always symmetrical, the severity of clinical symptoms increases in the evening. The first signs of the disease are severe burning and itching in the eye socket.

Hyperemia of the orbital and palpebral conjunctiva is visually determined in the area of the medial, rarely lateral corners.

Foamy mucus is released from the conjunctival cavity in a small volume, the consistency of which becomes viscous after 24-72 hours.

Pathological secretions accumulate in the corners of the eye slit.

Maceration of the skin in the periorbital zone is observed. Painful cracks form on the skin of the eyelids.

Treatment of angular conjunctivitis

  • Antibacterial drugs. The Morax-Axenfeld bacterium is sensitive to tetracyclines and aminoglycosides. In the absence of an effect reserve preparations are used – fluoroquinolones and combined antibacterial agents.
  • Antiseptic agents. In the complex treatment of angular conjunctivitis, the leading role is given to a solution of zinc sulfate. Instillation of eye drops is carried out 4-6 times a day for 1-1.5 months. After the symptoms are eliminated, the drug is instilled for another 7-10 days. The edges of the eyelids are carefully treated with zinc ointment.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. To reduce the severity of inflammation, instillations of 0.1% diclofenac sodium solution are used. In severe pathology, glucocorticosteroids are additionally prescribed.

 

 

Ref : https://medic-journal.com/eye-diseases/angular-conjunctivitis/

questions.text: A 28-year-old man visits a psychiatrist with complaints of persistent thoughts that his wife is unfaithful despite having no evidence or logical reason to suspect this. He reports that these thoughts are causing him great distress, leading to confrontations with his wife, and isolation from friends. His medical and drug history is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Othello syndrome

Explanation:

Othello syndrome is characterized by a delusion of infidelity, where the patient has a false, fixed belief that their spouse or sexual partner is being unfaithful, despite having no evidence to support this claim...

In Capgras syndrome, patient has a delusion that a familiar person (friend, spouse, parent, or other close family member) has been replaced by a similar looking stranger.

Mnemonic - Close Person Got Replaced by A Stranger

Fregoli syndrome: The patient believes that a familiar person is changing the physical appearance and disguising as a stranger. And that multiple different appearances can be taken by this person. Mnemonic- Familiar person giving goli

In Cotard syndrome, patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted

Shortening of motor blockade

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is posted for total colectomy under combined spinal -epidural anaesthesia. Intra-operatively and post-operatively he is given pain relief with fentanyl added in the epidural top up dose. Which of these adverse effects will you NOT expect in these patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Shortening of motor blockade

 

Epidural opioids enhance the sensory blockade of epidural local aesthetics and thus help in giving analgesia, without prolonging the motor blockade.

 

However, they do not shorten the time of motor blockade.

 

Advantages of using neuraxial opioids:

  • Enhance the analgesic effects of epidural local aesthetics
  • Prolong the duration of sensory and motor blockade.
  • Decrease the duration of motor block
  • Less hemodynamic instability as compared to with local anaesthetic alone.

 

 

Reference: Miller’s Anaesthesia 9th edition pg 1426, 1434

Children die within 5years.

MCC of death: CVS-Aneurysmal dissection/Cardiac rupture

Wilson disease results in liver damage & neuropsychiatric manifestations due to copper overload (defect – ATP7B)

questions.text: Which enzyme deficiency is likely responsible for the increased glycogen observed in the muscle biopsy of a 25-year-old male who experiences pain in his calves during exercise, with no other symptoms or signs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Muscle Phosphorylase

  • In the case of a 25-year-old male experiencing pain in his calves during exercise and increased glycogen observed in the muscle biopsy, the most likely enzyme deficiency would Muscle phosphorylase/myophosphorylase, indicating McArdle disease or Glycogen Storage Disease Type V.
  • This enzyme plays a key role in breaking down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which is further metabolized to produce energy during exercise. In McArdle disease, the impaired breakdown of glycogen leads to the accumulation of glycogen in muscle cells, causing exercise-induced muscle pain, cramps, and fatigue.

Option A) Muscle debranching enzyme:

  • The deficiency of muscle debranching enzyme, also known as amylo-1,6-glucosidase or glycogen debranching enzyme, leads to a glycogen storage disease known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (GSD III), also called Cori disease or Forbes disease.
  • In GSD III, there is an accumulation of abnormal glycogen with long outer branches in various tissues, including muscle. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down the outer branches of glycogen, and its deficiency results in impaired glycogen degradation.

Option C) Glucose 6 phosphatase:

  • Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with a group of disorders called Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I).
  • In GSD I, there is a deficiency of glucose 6 phosphatase in the liver and kidney, leading to impaired glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen) and gluconeogenesis (formation of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources).
  • The deficiency of glucose 6 phosphatase results in the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, including muscle, and manifests with symptoms like hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and growth retardation.

Option D) Branching enzyme:

  • Branching enzyme, also known as amylo-(1,4 to 1,6)-transglycosylase, is responsible for creating the branched structure of glycogen.
  • Deficiency of branching enzyme is associated with a glycogen storage disease called Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV (GSD IV), also known as Andersen disease.
  • In GSD IV, there is abnormal glycogen accumulation characterized by long, unbranched chains of glucose molecules. This leads to liver and muscle dysfunction, resulting in hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), liver cirrhosis, and muscle weakness.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis is prescribed a first line antitubercular drug that works by blocking the RNA polymerase enzyme. It exhibits a bactericidal effect against mycobacteria present both intracellularly and extracellularly. Which of the following drugs is the patient likely taking?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rifampicin

Explanation:

Rifampicin is a first line antitubercular drug that works by blocking the RNA polymerase enzyme, thus inhibiting the synthesis of mRNA and, consequently, protein synthesis. This mechanism of action gives it a bactericidal effect against mycobacteria, including those causing tuberculosis and leprosy, whether they are located intracellularly or extracellularly. The other drugs listed – Isoniazid, Ethambutol, and Pyrazinamide – also have antitubercular activity, but they do not function by blocking the RNA polymerase enzyme.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man hospitalized for 17 days and on IV antibiotics followed by oral course of drugs for acute febrile illness with neutropenia.  He had a history of dysuria while admitted and now complains of loose stools and abdominal pain.  Which antibiotic usage has highest risk for developing pseudomembranous colitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Amino-penicillin

Explanation:

Pseudomembranous colitis:

  • Antibiotics associated colitis, caused by Clostridium difficile.
  • Most common cause of healthcare-associated diarrhoea
  • Caused due to the loss of normal gut flora, after the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones to which the organism is resistant.
  • But may be caused by any antibiotics including Vancomycin & Metronidazole which are used for its treatment.
  • Two exotoxins, Toxin-A (enterotoxin ± cytotoxin) & Toxin-B (cytotoxin) are involved in its pathogenesis.

questions.text: A mother delivers twins with similar development, but very different features as shown below. On DNA testing, only one of the twins matches the husband. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superfecundation

  • Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus 
    • So twin pregnancy in both
  • Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:
  • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
  • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time
  • Whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

questions.text: Identify the nerve root(s) of the thickened nerve marked in the arrow in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. C2, C3

The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve.

 

Great auricular nerve:

The great auricular nerve is the cervical plexus's largest ascending branch, arising from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C2 and C3.

The nerve emerges just behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle's middle portion, curves around its posterior border, and emerges on the muscle's anterior surface.

The great auricular nerve perforates the deep cervical fascia and ascends along the external jugular vein, passing under the platysma muscle.

The great auricular nerve divides into terminal branches as it approaches the parotid gland.

Clinical considerations:

  • Leprosy - Nerve thickening is present. The nerve is palpable over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (As seen in the above image)
  • Frey's syndrome - An aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve causes gustatory sweating.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with co-infection of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Hepatitis B Virus (HBV). His doctor wishes to prescribe a single antiviral drug that would be effective against both viruses. Which of the following antiviral drugs should the doctor consider?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Emtricitabine

Emtricitabine is a NRTI that has dual action against both HIV and Hepatitis B. The drugs having activity against both HIV and HBV are:

L: Lamivudine

E: Emtricitabine

T: Tenofovir

questions.text: A drug X was given as continuous intravenous infusion at 2 mg/min. The clearance of the drug is 100 ml/min. With a half-life of 1.8 hours, what would be the steady state plasma concentration of a drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 0.02 mg/mL

 

Maintenance dose rate = Clearance x Steady State Plasma concentration

 

Or Steady state plasma concentration = Maintenance dose rate/Clearance


Maintenace dose rate = 2 mg/min

 

Clearance = 100 ml/min

 

So, Steady state PC = 2/100 = 0.02 mg/mL

questions.text: ‘c’ wave in JVP is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iso-volumetric contraction

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are: -

“a wave” corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.

“c wave” represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.

“x descent” corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

“v wave” represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.

“y descent” represents the passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after the tricuspid valve opening.

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted through the vector, Tsetse fly?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sleeping sickness

Sleeping sickness, also known as African trypanosomiasis, is a disease transmitted by the Tsetse fly. It is caused by the protozoan parasites of the genus Trypanosoma. The disease occurs in sub-Saharan regions. Symptoms of this disease include fever, headache, joint pain, and itching, followed by confusion, sensory disturbances, poor coordination, and disturbances in the sleep cycle, hence the name 'Sleeping sickness'.

choices.text: None of the above

questions.solution:
Ans. C. Heat rupture

Heat Rupture:

  • Due to excessive heat, skin contracts and ruptures
  • May resemble lacerations (rarely even incised wounds)
  • Blood vessels and nerves are intact in heat rupture
  • No Bleeding in the wound
  • Floor will show intact vessels / nerves

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with ischemic heart disease is posted for Coronary artery bypass graft surgery. You want beat to beat blood pressure measurement intraoperatively to guide you through the hemodynamic changes. Which among the following is the ideal artery for invasive blood pressure measurement?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Radial

Radial artery, because of ease of cannulation, presence of collateral blood flow and less associated complications, is the preferred for invasive blood pressure monitoring.

The other arteries which can be used for invasive blood pressure monitoring are

  • Ulnar,
  • Brachial,
  • Axillary,
  • Femoral arteries
  • Less commonly dorsalis pedis
  • Posterior tibial
  • Superficial temporal arteries.

 

 

Reference : Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition, page 155

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy, of African descent, presented with a large boggy mass on his scalp with overlying crusting. Skin scrapings and hair pluckings were taken for mycology. Microsporum canis was grown on culture. What is the most suitable treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral Griseofulvin

Explanation: Systemic treatment is needed for tinea capitis and for kerion, however topical treatment in addition may decrease transmission. Griseofulvin is FDA approved for and also the drug of choice in tinea capitis, It is the most commonly prescribed medication for tinea capitis treatment in children due to its cost-effectiveness and easy accessibility A recent Cochrane review suggested newer antifungal agents including terbinafine, itraconazole and fluconazole are at least as good as griseofulvin for the treatment of tinea capitis caused by trichophyton species, however, terbinafine was found to be less effective than griseofulvin for Microsporum infections. Griseofulvin is a microtubule assembly inhibitor. It interacts with microtubules to affect the formation of the mitotic spindle. This interference ultimately inhibits mitosis in dermatophytes. With this mechanism, griseofulvin serves as a fungistatic agent against Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton species.

 

 

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537323/

questions.text: A patient who had repeated episodes of ear discharge since few years presented with diplopia and retro-orbital pain. On otoscopy, mucopurulent discharge seen in the ear canal with perforated tympanic membrane. Identify the false statement regarding the diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diplopia is due to involvement of trochlear nerve

Petrositis (a complication of CSOM) is infection of petrous apex. 5th and 6th cranial nerves pass close to petrous apex. Trigeminal ganglion is present on anterior surface on petrous bone near it’s apex and abducens nerve passes in dorello canal just beneath the tip of petrous apex. Gradenigo’s triad is seen here – (1) deep-seated retro-orbital pain (due to V nerve involvement), (2) diplopia (due to VI nerve involvement) and (3) persistent ear discharge.
