questions.text: A 63-year-old man with COPD presents to you with dyspnea. Which of the following therapies is most likely to prolong his survival?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Oxygen

The only therapies that have been proven to improve survival in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are smoking cessation, oxygen in patients with resting hypoxemia, and lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) in a very small subset of highly selected patients. This patient probably has resting hypoxemia resulting from the presence of an elevated jugular venous pulse, pedal edema, and elevated hematocrit. Theophylline has been shown to increase exercise tolerance in patients with COPD through a mechanism other than bronchodilation. Oral glucocorticoids are not indicated in the absence of an acute exacerbation and may lead to complications if they are used indiscriminately. Atenolol and enalapril have no specific role in therapy for COPD but are often used when there is concomitant hypertension or cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: You have a patient who presents with a loss of sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. After thorough investigation, you believe this to be the result of damage to a specific cranial nerve nucleus that is part of the Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) column. However, upon review of the patient’s MRI scan, you come across an undamaged nucleus that you initially suspected to be involved in the SVA pathway. Which cranial nerve nucleus did you mistakenly believe to be a part of the SVA column, but is actually not?”
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

The trochlear nerve nucleus belongs to the general somatic efferent column (GSE), not the special visceral afferent column.

The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the orbit’s superior oblique muscle.

The neurons of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column innervate the extrinsic ocular and tongue muscles (III, IV, VI, and XII cranial nerves).

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with symptoms of depression and recent suicidal ideation. He has a history of frequent mood swings, irritability, and periods of intense euphoria followed by depressive episodes. The psychiatrist is considering adding a medication to his treatment regimen that has been shown to have anti-suicidal properties. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lithium

Explanation:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer frequently used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. One of the unique aspects of lithium, in comparison to other mood stabilizers and psychiatric medications, is its demonstrated anti-suicidal properties. Multiple studies have shown that lithium reduces suicide and all-cause mortality in patients with mood disorders, such as bipolar disorder and depression.

Fluoxetine is an SSRI antidepressant often used to treat depression and anxiety disorders but does not specifically have anti-suicidal properties. Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder but also does not have specific anti-suicidal properties. Donepezil is used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease and is not typically used for mood disorders or suicidality.

choices.text: Malabsorption of folate
Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.text: A female patient walked into the clinic presenting symptoms indicative of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. To address these issues, she was prescribed a treatment regimen consisting of 5mg folate. Following the course of treatment, doctors observed a notable improvement in the patient’s macrocytic anemia. However, contrary to their expectations, her neurological symptoms associated with peripheral neuropathy did not improve but instead worsened. Given these circumstances and the observed response to treatment, what could be the most likely cause explaining this unexpected clinical outcome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Folate therapy using the B12 stores

Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage.

The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.

Administration of folic acid for patients with macrocytic anemia can partially reverse the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with Type I diabetes develops a neuropathy limited to sensory neurons with free nerve endings. Quantitative sensory testing will reveal higher-than-normal thresholds for the detection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D Temperature

  • Quantitative sensory testing will show higher-than-normal thresholds for the detection of Temperature. 
  • Quantitative Sensory Testing measures changes in sensitivity to different types of sensations that can include temperature, touch, or pressure.
  • Free nerve endings contain receptors for temperature, pain, and crude touch. However, fine touch, pressure, and vibration are detected by nerve endings contained within specialized capsules that transmit the stimulus to the sensory receptors.
  • Muscle length is encoded by the primary nerve endings of Ia fibers, which are located on intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindle.
  • There are four types of diabetic neuropathy:
  • Peripheral neuropathy (also called diabetic nerve pain and distal polyneuropathy)
  • Proximal neuropathy (also called diabetic amyotrophy)
  • Autonomic neuropathy
  • Focal neuropathy (also called mononeuropathy)
  • Peripheral neuropathy is nerve damage caused by chronically high blood sugar and diabetes. It leads to numbness, loss of sensation, and sometimes pain in your feet, legs, or hands. It is the most common complication of diabetes
  • Peripheral neuropathy is nerve damage caused by chronically high blood sugar and diabetes. It leads to numbness, loss of sensation, and sometimes pain in your feet, legs, or hands. It is the most common complication of diabetes.

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has recently been diagnosed with hypertension. His doctor started him on a new antihypertensive medication. One week later, he presents to the emergency department with significant swelling of his lips and tongue. Which of the following antihypertensive medications is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lisinopril

The given picture is suggestive of angioedema. The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option. Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.

The other side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are :-

  • Cough
  • Taste disturbances (Dysgeusia)
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

choices.text: It is the most commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure.
Chromosomal microarray can be performed on uncultured amniocytes
Blood-tinged amniotic fluid is seen in transplacental passage of the needle
Procedure related loss rate is 1 -2% when performed by an experienced provider.

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Procedure related loss rate is 1-2% when performed by an experienced provider

Explanation: 

  • Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure.
  • Indications for amniocentesis include:
    • Diagnosis of fetal genetic disorders
    • Diagnosis of Congenital infection
    • Evaluation of anemia in Rh alloimmunization
    • Determination of Fetal lung maturity
  • Following amniocentesis, genetic analysis can be done using
    1. Chromosomal microarray (CMA) – to assess copy number gains or losses: can be performed directly on uncultured amniocytes 
    2. Karyotype analysis for aneuploidy requires cultures amniocytes
    3. FISH to identify gain or loss of specific chromosomes. 
  • Procedure: 
    • Ultrasound guided
    • Done between 15- 20weeks
    • Anterior placentation seen in 60% and blood-tinged fluid is more frequent if there is transplacental passage of the needle.
    • For fetal karyotype, about 20 -30 ml withdrawn.
  • Procedure related loss: 0.1 – 0.3 % when performed by an experienced provider. 
  • Early amniocentesis (11-14 weeks): significantly higher rate of procedure related complications; like clubfoot, amnionic fluid leakage and fetal loss. Not done anymore. 

 

 

Ref: Page No 292, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with a right-sided facial palsy and tinnitus. Which virus is most likely to have caused his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Varicella Zoster virus

Explanation Varicella-zoster virus

The Ramsay Hunt syndrome is characterized by facial palsy secondary to a varicella-zoster infection of the external ear or tympanic membrane, with involvement of the facial or auditory nerves. Associated symptoms may include tinnitus, vertigo, and deafness.

questions.text: A 22-year-old collage going adult has history of sexual exposure with commercial sex worker, now presenting with painful genital lesions and lymphadenopathy in right inguinal region. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chancroid

Explanation:

The differential diagnosis of genital ulcers:

Syphilis: (Treponema pallidum)

Incubation Period: 9-90 days

No. of lesions: usually one

Induration: firm

Pain: uncommon

Lymphadenopathy: firm, non-tender, bilateral

 

Herpes: (Herpes simplex virus 1 & 2)

Incubation Period: 2-7 days

No. of lesions: multiple

Induration: none

Pain: frequently tender

Lymphadenopathy: firm, tender, often bilateral

 

Chancroid: (Haemophilus ducreyi)

Incubation Period: 1-14 days

No. of lesions: usually multiple

Induration: soft

Pain: usually very tender

 

Lymphadenopathy: tender, usually unilateral

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): (C. trachomatis)

Incubation Period: 3 days – 6 weeks

No. of lesions: usually one, often not detected

Induration: occasionally firm

Pain: variable

Lymphadenopathy: tender, usually unilateral

 

Donovanosis: (Klebsiella granulomatis)

Incubation Period: 1-4 weeks

No. of lesions: variable

Induration: firm

Pain: uncommon

Lymphadenopathy: none, Pseudobuboes present

questions.text: According to Barcelona clinic for liver cancer which of these agents is approved for advanced hepatoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sorafenib

Sorafenib is an oral multi-kinase inhibitor that has effects on tumor cell proliferation and tumor angiogenesis. It also increases the rate of apoptosis in cancer cells. It's been shown to extend survival times in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), the most common type of primary liver cancer.

In multiple clinical trials, such as the SHARP trial, Sorafenib was found to significantly improve overall survival in patients with advanced HCC. As a result, the Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer (BCLC) staging system and treatment strategy - an internationally accepted system for HCC management - approves and recommends the use of Sorafenib in advanced cases of the disease.

questions.text: ALOPECIA, MADAROSIS, SKIN RASH, PAINFUL PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY AND CONFUSION WITH LETHARGY ARE SEEN IN which poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Thallium poisoning

  • The combination of alopecia & skin rash, painful peripheral neuropathy and confusion with lethargy are known as ‘Thallium triad’.
  • It is indicative of chronic thallium poisoning.
  • Both thallium and arsenic have many similar features (both have Mees lines, peripheral neuropathies, GI symptoms, skin symptoms etc..). But the key differentiation feature is thallium is associated more with alopecia, whereas, arsenic more with GI symptoms.
  • Madarosis is loss of eyebrows and eyelashes, esp. seen in thallium

questions.text: The following Pap smear shows infestation by:

Ans. D. Actinomyces

Explanation:

  • The picture shows a dense network of Gram-positive filamentous structures in a pap smear suggestive of sulphur  granule of Actinomyces infection
  • Pelvic involvement in Actinomyces infection is seen in association with IUCDs.
  • Starts as endometritis progressing to pelvic masses or tuboovarian abcess
  • May be misdiagnosed as malignancy or endometriosis in advanced stage.

Important points:

questions.text: A patient of peptic ulcer was prescribed ranitidine and sucralfate in the morning hours. Why is this combination incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act.

  • Sucralfate is an ulcer protective agent. It forms a coating over the ulcer base after polymerization.  Sucralfate polymerizes only at acidic pH (<4). Ranitidine is an H2 blocker that reduces the gastric acid secretion. If both of these drugs are combined, action of sucralfate will be abolished due to rise in pH by ranitidine.
  • Option a is incorrect as ranitidine does not combine with sucralfate.
  • Option b is incorrect as agranulocytosis is not a common side effect of this combination.
  • Option d is also incorrect as sucralfate does not inhibit the absorption of ranitidine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Ans. ‘D’ Hypoglycemia

Beta 2 agonists stimulate glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis resulting in increase in blood sugar. These do not cause hypoglycemia.

Adverse Effects of beta-2 agonists

  • Tremors: Most common adverse effect of beta 2 agonists is tremors. It occurs due to stimulation of beta 2 receptors on skeletal muscle spindles.
  • Tachycardia: At high dose, beta 2 agonists can result in tachycardia due to loss of selectivity.
  • T-wave changes in ECG: Beta 2 agonists can result in hypokalaemia due to intracellular shift of potassium. This can lead to ECG changes.
  • Tolerance: A reduction in the bronchodilator response to low-dose β-agonist treatment can be shown after several days of regular β-agonist use, but maximal bronchodilation is still achieved well within the range of doses usually given.

choices.text: The central part of the hard palate's bony structure is covered by a firmly attached mucosa
The keratinised stratified squamous epithelium of the hard palate can be orthokeratinised or parakeratinised
The mucosa that covers the hard palate has a distinct keratinized layer known as the stratum corneum
The hard palate lacks a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the hard palate is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The hard palate lacks a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts.

Explanation: This statement is incorrect. The hard palate does indeed have a submucosal layer and it contains blood vessels, particularly in the lateral parts. This layer is crucial for nourishing the overlying mucosa and also houses minor salivary glands, especially towards the back of the hard palate.

The hard palate is made up of keratinised stratified squamous epithelium, a submucosa, and a minor salivary gland. This keratinised stratified squamous epithelium varies regionally and can be orthokeratinised or parakeratinised (found in hard palate and gingiva).

The central part of the hard palate's bony structure is covered by a firmly attached mucosa. The hard palate has a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts. Minor mucous salivary glands can be found in the submucosa in the back of the hard palate.

The mucosa that covers the hard palate has a distinct keratinized layer known as the stratum corneum. Capillaries also loop up into connective tissue papillae.

The presence of relatively high connective tissue papillae projecting into the overlying epithelium is a distinguishing feature of keratinized regions in the oral cavity. Keratinized epithelium is associated with high connective tissue papillae. In the oral cavity, this type of keratinization is known as orthokeratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

(Note: In the orthokeratinized epithelium, cell nuclei disappear in the keratinized layer, whereas in the parakeratinized epithelium, flattened, highly condensed nuclei remain in the keratinized layer's cell cytoplasm until exfoliation)

choices.text: Step up antibiotics

questions.text: A 25-year-old male following RTA is brought to the casualty. Examination reveals bruising on left side of chest. Vitals are normal, Oxygen saturation is 98% without supplemental Oxygen. Chest X ray shows fracture of left 4th/5th ribs, otherwise normal. Following admission, he complains of hemoptysis and his O2 levels starts falling. Next step would be?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. O2 supplementation

The delayed drop in saturation and haemoptysis is suggestive of pulmonary contusion.

The natural progression of pulmonary contusion is worsening hypoxaemia for the first 24–48 hours. Chest radiographic findings may be typically delayed. Contrast CT scanning can be confirmatory. Haemoptysis or blood in the endotracheal tube is a sign of pulmonary contusion. In mild contusion, the treatment is oxygen administration, pulmonary toilet and adequate analgesia. In more severe cases mechanical ventilation is necessary.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flexion

Indicated muscles are Lumbricals which are responsible for flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.

Each of the four lumbrical (worm-like) muscles is associated with one of the fingers.

The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus in the palm give rise to the muscles:

  • The medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively;
  • The lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively.

The lumbrical muscles have tendons that pass over the outer side of each finger and attach to the extensor hood. They are located in front of the deep transverse metacarpal ligaments.

These muscles are unique because they connect the flexor tendons with the extensor tendons. By inserting into the extensor hoods, they help in flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints.

The medial two lumbricals are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, while the lateral two lumbricals are supplied by digital branches of the median nerve.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents with complains of a six-month history of amenorrhea, galactorrhoea and an increasingly severe frontal headache. On further questioning she has had several near misses while driving recently but denies any visual problems. She has no past medical or surgical history and takes no regular medicines. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband and works as a teacher. She is happy in her work and not stressed. Neurological examination reveals a visual field defect but is otherwise normal. Given the likely diagnosis, which visual field defect is expected?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Bitemporal hemianopia

Prolactinoma is a noncancerous tumor of the pituitary gland. This tumor causes the pituitary gland to make too much of a hormone called prolactin- the major effect of which is decreased levels of sex hormones — namely, estrogen and testosterone.

A prolactinoma isn't life-threatening. But it can cause vision difficulties, infertility and other problems. Prolactinoma is the most common type of hormone-producing tumor that can develop in the pituitary gland.

Females who are premenopausal tend to notice signs and symptoms early, when tumors are smaller in size. This is probably because of missed or irregular menstrual periods. Females who are postmenopausal are more likely to notice signs and symptoms later, when tumors are larger and more likely to cause headache or vision problems. Males are also more likely to notice signs and symptoms later.

 

Chiasmal Field Deficits

Characteristically lesions at the level of the optic chiasm produce a bitemporal hemianopia. While these field defects typically respect the vertical midline, pituitary adenomas large enough to cause compression tend to also reduce visual acuity. Vison loss due to compression first affects the superotemporal visual fields, then inferotemporal, inferonasal and finally superonasal fields.

Monocular Visual Field Deficits

Asymmetric tumors may preferentially involve one side of the chiasm or an optic nerve, and most commonly presents as a superotemporal quadrantanopsia. The incidence of pituitary adenomas presenting as monocular visual field defects was reported to be 9%.

questions.text: When capillary and interstitial hydrostatic pressures are 3 mm of Hg and 0 mm of Hg and colloid oncotic pressure of capillaries and interstitium is 25 mm of Hg and 5 mm of Hg, What is the Net filtration pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 17 mm Hg

Net Filtration Pressure = kf [(Pc - Pi) - (πc-πi)]

  • Replacing the values we get;
  • Net Filtration Pressure = (3 — 0) — (25 — 5)

                                                     = -17mm Hg

  • The minus sign indicates that fluid movement is inward into the capillary.
  • So the answer is 17 mm Hg.

The rate of filtration at any point along a capillary depends on a balance of forces called the Starling forces which are:

Net Filtration Pressure = k [(Pc - Pi) - (πc-πi)]

k = Capillary filtration coefficient

Pc = Capillary hydrostatic pressure

Pi = Interstitial hydrostatic pressure

πc = Capillary colloid osmotic pressure

πi = Interstitial colloid osmotic pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Mycoplasma pneumoniae?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Responds well to Co-Amoxiclav

Explanation:

  • Mycoplasmas are the smallest free-living organisms that can be grown in a cell free media.
  • These organisms are unique among prokaryotes in that they lack a cell wall.  They are bounded by a soft trilaminar unit membrane containing sterols.
  • Lack of cell wall provides it certain unique properties:
    • Pleomorphic with no fixed shape or sizeSZ
    • Pass through bacterial filters
    • Resistant  to  beta  lactams  -  penicillins  & cephalosporins
    • Lack of reaction to Gram stain
  • Cause ‘Primary atypical pneumonia’ in about 3-13% of infected individuals
  • Causes peribronchial pneumonia with interstitial infiltration and subsegmental atelectasis

Laboratory diagnosis:

Culture: On PPLO broth

Serology:

  • Non-specific  tests:  Streptococcus  MG  test  &  Cold  agglutinin test
  • Specific test: IF, HAI, CFT, IHA, Growth inhibition test

Molecular methods: PCR test

choices.text: Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 with the aim to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020.
Intensified Mission Indradhanush was an amendment in 2017 that aimed to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases.
Both the programs consisted of 4 rounds of immunization, each round held for 7 days each month.
Pneumococcal meningitis was one of the diseases covered under the original Mission Indradhanush, while Rubella was included in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding Mission Indradhanush and Intensified Mission Indradhanush?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Pneumococcal meningitis was one of the diseases covered under the original Mission Indradhanush, while Rubella was included in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush.
 

Pneumococcal meningitis was not covered under the original Mission Indradhanush, but was added later in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush. Similarly, Rubella was not included in the original Mission Indradhanush, but was indeed part of the diseases added in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush.
 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.


The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio (OPV)
  • atitis B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B disease (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • IPV

choices.text: Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium
Thiazides act as an add on drug to lithium

Thiazides cause water loss thereby increase lithium levels

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy developed hypertension. He was started on thiazides for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Explain the likely mechanism of this interaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thiazides increase the tubular resorption of lithium

Thiazide diuretics act by blocking the Na-Cl channel in the DCT. This leads to natriuresis as well as diuresis. After a few days , there occurs compensation by increasing the absorption of Na from the PCT. The kidney handles both lithium and Na+ in the same way. Thus, along with Na+ reabsorption, there will be an increase in the reabsorption of lithium also. Thus, the concurrent use of thiazides and lithium can precipitate toxicity of lithium.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of bone pain in his lower back, ribs, and hips. He also reports fatigue, weakness, and unintentional weight loss. On physical examination, he has diffuse tenderness to palpation in the areas of reported bone pain. Laboratory studies reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated serum protein levels. A plain X-ray of her femur reveals the following. A bone scan in this patient would likely show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Cold spots

Explanation

This clinical scenario and image showing multiple lytic lesions are suggestive of multiple myeloma. This condition presents with cold spots on bone scans as there is a lack of compensatory osteoblastic activity.

A cold spot on a bone scan in a patient with multiple myeloma could indicate a site of decreased bone metabolism, which may be suggestive of a bone lesion. Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells, which can lead to the destruction of bone tissue and the development of bone lesions.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is treated with chemotherapy for lung cancer He presents with fever of 38.3°C (100.9°F). He is found to have erythema at the exit site of tunneled central venous catheter in the neck, although the tunnel itself is not tender or red. Blood cultures are negative at 48 hours. His neutrophil count is 1550/μL. What is the best approach to he management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Treatment with vancomycin alone

Clinicians are often faced with treatment decisions regarding potential catheter-related infections in patients who are immunocompromised from cancer and chemotherapy. Because many patients require several weeks of chemotherapy, tunneled catheters are often placed, and determining the need for catheter removal is an important consideration. When blood cultures are positive or there is evidence of infection along the track of the tunnel, catheter removal is recommended. When the erythema is limited to the exit site only, then it is not necessary to remove the catheter unless the erythema fails to respond to treatment. The recommended treatment for an exit site infection should be directed against coagulase-negative staphylococci. In the options presented, vancomycin alone is the best option for treatment.

questions.text: Fixing a strip of External Oblique Aponeurosis to re-inforce the inguinal canal is called:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Desarda's repair

Desarda has described an operation where a 1- to 2-cm strip of external oblique aponeurosis lying over the inguinal canal is isolated from the main muscle, but left attached both medially and laterally. It is then sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament, reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. As the abdominal muscles contract, this strip of aponeurosis tightens to add further physiological support to the posterior wall. This operation is currently seen as equivalent to Shouldice repair.

These inclusion criteria were adopted as the “Milan criteria”, with angioinvasion and extrahepatic involvement as additional exclusion criteria, and are now universally accepted.

  1. Due to the decreased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants, matched related donor transplants are still favoured over unrelated donor transplants.
  2. Rh incompatibility has no impact on the success of transplants (Rh antigen is only found on the surface of RBCs, not on the parenchymal cells of the graft).

Option A. Syngeneic transplantation (donation from identical twins) has been shown to increase the risk of relapse in cases of hematologic malignancies and is therefore not a source of donor that is advised.

Option B. Umblical cord transplant is not usually recommended.

Option C. Matched unrelated donors are NOT preferred and inferior to matched related donors

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding measurements taken for the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) examination?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. GH is measured from the midline of the posterior hymenal ring to the mid-anal opening

Explanation

  • In 1996, the International Continence Society defined the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system.
  • Prolapse in each segment is measured relative to the hymen, which is an anatomic landmark that can be identified consistently.
  • Six points are located with reference to the plane of the hymen: two on the anterior vaginal wall (points Aa and Ba), two at the apical vagina (points C and D), and two on the posterior vaginal wall (points Ap and Bp)
  • The genital hiatus (Gh), perineal body (Pb), and total vaginal length (TVL) are also measured.
  • All POP-Q points, except TVL, are measured during patient Valsalva and should reflect maximum protrusion.
  • Anterior Vaginal Wall Points
    • Point Aa defines a point that lies in the midline of the anterior vaginal wall and is 3 cm proximal to the external urethral meatus. This corresponds to the proximal location of the urethra-vesical crease.
    • Point Ba represents the most distal position of any part of the upper anterior vaginal wall, that is, the segment of vagina that normally would extend cephalad rom point Aa. It is –3 cm in the absence of prolapse.
  • Apical Vaginal Points
    • Point C defines a point that is at either the most distal edge of the cervix or the leading edge of the vaginal cuff after total hysterectomy.
    • Point D defines a point that represents the location of the posterior fornix in a woman who still has a cervix. It is omitted in the absence of a cervix.
  • Posterior Vaginal Wall Points Point
    •  Ap defines a point in the midline of the posterior vaginal wall that lies 3cm proximal to the hymen.
    • Point Bp represents the most distal position of any part of the upper posterior vaginal wall.
  • Genital Hiatus, Perineal Body and Total vaginal length
    • Te genital hiatus (gh) is measured from the middle of the external urethral meatus to the midline of the posterior hymenal ring.
    • The perineal body is measured from the posterior margin of the genital hiatus to the mid-anal opening

 

Ref: Page no 541, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought by her mother to her primary care physician with a history of chronic shortness of breath and fatigue. She reports that her symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past year, and she is no longer able to perform her usual activities of daily living without experiencing significant dyspnea. On physical examination, the physician notes a prominent jugular venous pulse with a giant "a" wave and a soft systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. An electrocardiogram shows right atrial enlargement, right ventricular hypertrophy, and right bundle branch block. An echocardiogram is ordered, which reveals a displaced tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, with severe tricuspid regurgitation and a small right ventricle. What is the likely appearance on CXR?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Box shaped heart

Explanation

The given scenario describes a typical case of Ebstein anomaly. The CXR depicts an enlarged, box-shaped cardiac silhouette, that is characteristically seen in Ebstein's anomaly.

Option A: Egg in cup sign: Calcific pericarditis typically appears as a dense, curvilinear, or band-like opacity that surrounds the heart, often described as a "shaggy heart" appearance. The calcification can also extend into the adjacent mediastinal fat, creating a dense, well-defined line that separates the heart from the lungs.

Option B: Egg on side: This is a radiological sign seen in TGA. Transposition of the Great Arteries, which is a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary artery and aorta, are switched (or "transposed") in position. This means that the aorta arises from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle.

Option C: Money bag sign is typically seen in pericardial effusion.

 

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 150

choices.text: Population attributable risk

questions.text: In a case-control study examining the association between smoking and lung cancer, which of the following measures of association is most appropriately used?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Odds ratio

Case-control studies are retrospective, and they start with the outcome (disease) and look back to investigate the exposure. In these types of studies, we usually cannot measure risk directly because the denominator, the total number of people at risk (i.e., the total number of people from whom the cases arose), is not known. Therefore, odds ratio is the most appropriate measure of association to use in case-control studies. Odds ratio compares the odds of exposure among cases to the odds of exposure among controls. The other measures - relative risk, attributable risk, and population attributable risk - are more appropriately used in cohort studies where the investigator starts with the exposure and follows up the subjects to see who develops the disease.

questions.text: At birth the remnants of the umbilical vein become?

Explanation

  • Deoxygenated Blood exits the fetus through Umbilical arteries

    • Anatomical closure: 2 – 3months

    • Distal part form the lateral umbilical ligaments
  • Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from umbilical vein to IVC

  • Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from Pulmonary artery to Aorta
    • Functional closure: 12 – 24 h
    • Anatomic closure: 2 – 3 weeks
    • Becomes the ligamentum arteriosum
  • Foramen ovale
    • Functional closure soon after birth
    • Anatomical closure at 1 year

questions.text: A modified biophysical profile is done for a 38-week primigravida complaining of decreased fetal movements. The NST is reactive. The 2nd component of the test is as shown below. What is your inference?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. There is oligohydramnios

 

Explanation

 

  • The image shows the 4 quadrants taken to measure the amniotic fluid index (AFI)
  • The 1st quadrant has no amniotic fluid, hence the measurement is 0
  • By adding all 4 quadrants, we get the AFI
  • In this case, the AFI is 0 + 1.3 + 1.6 + 2.1 = 5
  • Oligohydramnios is defined as an AFI < 5 and is an indication for delivery in a term patient as it signifies utero-placental insufficiency

 

 

Ref: Page 667, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly used radiation sensitizer for the treatment of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Cisplatin

Explanation

  • Current evidence indicates that chemotherapy given concurrently with radiation therapy significantly improves overall and disease- free survival rates of women with cervical cancer.
  • Chemoradiation is also associated with superior survival rates compared with pelvic and extended- eld paraaortic region irradiation alone.
  • Cisplatin based chemotherapy should be considered in women undergoing radiation or cervical cancer
  • Of chemotherapy agents, cisplatin-containing regimens have been associated with the best survival rates

 

 

Ref: Page 673, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Which statistical test is used to determine if there is a significant association between two categorical variables?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Chi Square test

The Chi Square test is used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. In this case, the two categorical variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban).

choices.text: Maxillary → sphenopalatine → greater palatine → anterior ethmoidal
Sphenopalatine → maxillary → greater palatine → posterior ethmoidal
Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → anterior ethmoidal
Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → posterior ethmoidal

questions.text: A patient presented with severe nasal bleed after a road traffic accident. It did not stop even after anterior and posterior nasal packing. Next immediate step to be planned is ligation of arteries that supply nasal cavity. What is the sequence you follow while ligating?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Sphenopalatine → maxillary → external carotid → anterior ethmoidal

Epistaxis –

Most common site – little’s area, most common cause in children is nose picking and in adults is hypertension. Foreign bodies in nose generally cause unilateral bleeding. Adolescent males with profuse bleeding should be suspected of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). Other causes include septal spur, patients on anticoagulants, patients on topical steroid sprays for long durations, granulomatous diseases, bleeding disorders like haemophilia and genetic conditions like hereditary haemorrhagic telangiectasia.

Rx – Initially Trotter’s method (pinch the nose tightly and sit bending forwards). Chemical cauterisation by applying silver nitrate at the bleeding site. Anterior nasal packing and if doesn’t stop, posterior nasal packing done. Still not controlled, then ligation techniques done. Preferably TESPAL (Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation) done at the sphenopalatine foramen area (1cm behind the end of middle turbinate). If still not controlled, then maxillary artery ligation done in pterygopalatine fossa (approached by Caldwell-luc method and then removing posterior wall of maxillary sinus also). Next artery to be ligated if still bleeding continues is External carotid artery (done above the level of branching of superior thyroid artery from it because thyroid vascularity can’t be compromised). If still uncontrollable bleed occurs, then it is from the branches of internal carotid artery. So, anterior ethmoidal artery tried first ligating at the medial wall of orbit 24mm posterior to anterior lacrimal crest.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Mirrizzi syndrome

Jaundice may ensue if the gallstone migrates from the gallbladder and obstructs or compresses the CBD (Mirizzi).

Rarely, a large solitary gallstone may erode the gallbladder wall, causing a cholecysto-duodenal fistula and subsequent bowel obstruction, known as gallstone ileus.

choices.text: To reduce the uptake of glucose
To increase its lifespan and become immortal
To make intermediated required for proliferation

questions.text: The likely explanation for a cancer cell exhibiting the Warburg effect is?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. To make intermediated required for proliferation

Robbins 10th/ 299

  • Warburg effect is aerobic glycolysis. In cancer cells, even in the presence of ample oxygen, there is a high level of glucose uptake (so, option ‘a’ is incorrect) and increased conversion of glucose to lactose via the glycolytic pathway (only 2 ATP generated in place of 36 ATP and so, option ‘c’ is incorrect).
  • Warburg effect enables the synthesis of the macromolecules and organelles that are needed for rapid cell growth.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male complains of fever and pain right hip. On examination he has swelling in right hip region, flexion, abduction and external rotation at hip and there is mild reduction in movements in right hip region. On X-ray there is mild increase in medial joint space. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Ans: B. Transient synovitis

choices.text: Fracture of acetabulum
TB of hip

questions.text: Wandering acetabulum is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. TB of hip

  • Wandering acetabulum is seen in tuberculosis of hip, stage 4 when destroyed head dislocates from the acetabulum.
  • Stage 1: Stage of synovitis - FABER (Flexion, Abduction and External rotation). Lengthening.
  • Stage 2: Stage of early arthritis - FADIR + <1 cm shortening (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation).
  • Stage 3: Stage of advanced arthritis - FADIR +>1 cm shortening (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation).
  • Stage 4: Stage of subluxation/dislocation wandering acetabulum or pestle and mortar appearance.
  • Stage 5: Stage of sequelae, ankylosis or severe arthritis.

Wandering acetabulum (actually wandering femur head)

questions.text: An old man being evaluated for abdominal pain and weight loss undergoes endoscopy showing a broad region of the gastric wall in which the rugae are flattened. Biopsy of this area shows infiltration by numerous polygonal tumor cells with small, dark, round or ovoid nuclei pushed to the margin of the cell by large, clear, cytoplasmic structures. These cells might be expected to have which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Positive staining for mucin by light micros­copy

The history given in the stem of the question suggests a gastric adenocarcinoma having an accumulation of mucin type glands leading to signet ring appearance. Hence the answer is option “d”.  

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 785

choices.text: IgA nephropathy is likely diagnosis
Her C3 levels will be low
No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy
Alport syndrome is likely diagnosis

questions.text: A 7 years old girl is brought with complaints of generalised swelling of the body. Urinary examination reveals grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. She has no history of hematuria. Which of the following statements about her condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy

  • The clinical symptoms and the findings in the stem of the question (child with generalised swelling because of reduced serum protein secondary to massive proteinuria with urinary lipid casts) are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. The commonest cause in a child of nephrotic syndrome is lipoid nephrosis or minimal change disease. So option ‘a’ and ‘d’ are ruled out. Both cause hematuria as a finding.
  • Electron microscopic examination in minimal change disease show the presence of effacement of foot processes of podocytes.

 

 

Ref: Robbin’s 10th/ 914

questions.text: All of the following are complications of supracondylar fracture of humerus in children, except:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Non-union

Complications of Fracture Supracondylar Humerus

1. Malunion Most Common Complication

    Posteromedially displaced fracture tend to develop Cubitus varus (gun stock deformity).

  • Cubitus varus deformity in fracture supracondylar humerus is managed by French/modified French osteotomy (lateral closing wedge osteotomy).
  • Baumans Angle-angle between the physis and long axis of humerus normal value 75-90 degrees it is increased in cubitus varus

2. Vascular (brachial artery) injury

3. Nerve injury (anterior interosseous n.> median n. >radial n>ulnar. n): These are usually neuropraxia, hence transient.

4. Volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome

5. Elbow stiffness

6. Myositis ossificans

7. Avascular necrosis of trochlea. (rare)

8. Tardy ulnar nerve palsy

questions.text: An elderly man who has worked in a manufacturing plant all his life complains of a 6-month history of chest discomfort, malaise, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. A chest X-ray reveals a pleural effusion and pleural mass encasing the lung. The patient subsequently dies of cardiorespiratory failure. Histologic examination of the pleural mass at autopsy shows a biphasic pattern of epithelial and sarcomatous elements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Malignant mesothelioma

Mesothelioma is a malignant neoplasm of mesothelial cells that is most common in the pleura, but also occurs in the peritoneum, pericardium, and the tunica vaginalis of the testis.

The tumor is strongly linked to occupational inhalation of asbestos.

Patients are often first seen with a pleural effusion or a pleural mass, chest pain, and nonspecific symptoms, such as weight loss and malaise.

Mesothelioma is typically composed of both epithelial and sarcomatous elements (i.e., biphasic pattern). The other choices do not ordinarily encase the lung.

questions.text: Type 1 MHC presents peptide antigen to T cell, so that peptide binding site is formed by:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Distal domain alfa 1 and 2

  • The antigen binding cleft is made up distal alpha 1 and 2 chains in MHC I molecule.
  • The antigen binding cleft is made up distal alpha 1 and beta 1 chains in MHC II molecule.

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the hospital with hematemesis. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, physical examination reveals splenomegaly and ascites, and initial hematocrit is 25%. Prior to endoscopy, which of the following is the best initial management of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A 60-year-old male patient with hepatitis C with a previous history of variceal bleeding is Administration of intravenous octreotide 

 

Hypervolaemia due to aggressive fluid resuscitation may increase portal pressure and exacerbate bleeding.

 

Ten milligrams of vitamin K are administered intravenously but a coagulopathy requires FFP and activation of a major transfusion protocol.

 

Thrombocytopenia secondary to hypersplenism is treated if the platelet count is × 109 /L.

 

Treatment protocols include the use of splanchnic vasoconstrictors, such as terlipressin, octreotide and somatostatin, and prophylactic antibiotics. When bleeding continues treatment options are sclerotherapy, banding, balloon tamponade and TIPSS.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy punctures his thumb with a rusty nail. Four hours later, the thumb appears red and swollen.  Which of the following serum proteins activate the complement, coagulation and fibrinolytic systems at the site of injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Hageman factor

Hageman factor (clotting factor XII) provides a key source of vasoactive mediators. It acts by stimulating

  • Conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, which induces fibrinolysis;
  • Conversion of prekallikrein to kallikrein, which generates bradykinin
  •  Activation of the alternative complement pathway; and
  •  Activation of the coagulation system.

choices.text: Birth control pills

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a female contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Ans: B Condom

Explanation:

Although condoms are a contraceptive method used during sexual intercourse, they are not specifically a "female" contraceptive option. They are typically used by males, although there are also female condoms. The other options listed (IUD, birth control pills, and tubal ligation) are specifically for females. An IUD is a small device inserted into the uterus to prevent pregnancy, birth control pills are taken orally to prevent ovulation, and tubal ligation is a surgical procedure that permanently blocks the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy.

choices.text: Negative selective of T cells in thymus

questions.text: All of the following can contribute to autoimmunity except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Negative selective of T cells in thymus

Negative selection of the T cells is a defense mechanism to reduce the chances of autoimmune disorders. It is achieved through the process of apoptosis.

questions.text: Most direct marker of CHD is?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. LDL

Elevated LDL-C has persisted as a leading modifiable risk factor and is one of the most closely linked markers of atherosclerotic CVD

questions.text: An elderly male with dragging sensation in abdomen presents in the OPD. His cell count had elevated total leucocyte count and increased platelet count. His peripheral smear shows metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophilia and basophilia (image given for reference). Which of the following is the likely genetic anomaly present in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. t (9; 22)

The increased cell count (leucocytes and platelets) with peripheral smear showing metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophilia and basophilia (mixed myeloid lineage) is suggestive of a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia.

Two other features:

  • Age of the patient (peak incidence in 5/6th decade of life)
  • The dragging sensation (can be due to splenomegaly seen in CML patients) also fits in the diagnosis.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p622

choices.text: The program was launched in 1992.
DOTS strategy was implemented as a part of this program.
The program focuses exclusively on the treatment and control of pulmonary tuberculosis.
The program aims to detect at least 70% of the estimated infectious TB cases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT correct about the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) in India?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. The program focuses exclusively on the treatment and control of pulmonary tuberculosis.

Explanation:

The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) came in 1992 by the Government of India with the aim of detecting at least 70% of the estimated infectious TB cases and curing at least 85% of these detected cases. The program uses the Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course (DOTS) strategy which is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO). However, the program does not solely focus on the treatment and control of pulmonary tuberculosis, it also addresses other forms of TB including extra-pulmonary tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with the following laboratory values: hemoglobin 9gm%, MCV is 55%, RBC is 4.5 million/mm3. There is no history of blood transfusion. What is the most likely diagnosis out of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Thalassemia minor

Thalassemia major patient presents with severe anemia and cannot survive without blood transfusion, so this option can be easily ruled out. For other options, Mentzer index is useful for differentiating between thalassemia minor and iron deficiency anemia.

  • Mentzer index is calculated as MCV/RBC count.
  • Its value is >13 in iron deficiency anemia and <13 in thalassemia minor.
  • For our given question, the value on calculation comes out to be 55/4.5 = 12.22.
  • As the value is < 13, so it is a case of thalassemia minor.
